prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose 5.3 hours of ALMA observations to obtain high-S/N CO(1-0) & 13CO(1-0) [Band 3] and CO(2-1) & 13CO(2-1) [Band 6] maps with single pointing & 3-point mosaic for Band 3 & 4 observaitons to cover 2 merging galaxies, NGC 1614 and NGC 3110. These observations require the extended configulation (1".0) of ALMA.
We expect peak 13CO(1-0) emission from the results with cycle 0 ALMA observations (Saito et al. 2013). Our 1".7 x 1".2 resolution 13CO(1-0) observation toward VV114 has a peak of 5 mJy/beam. Since our targets show similar infrared luminosities to VV114 and adopting the well-known molecular gas and SFR relation (Kennicutt 1998), our targets might have similar amount of molecular gas mass. This is comfirmed by our Mopra CO survey (Tateuchi & Kaneko et al. in prep.). We need at least S/N = 5 for a robust determination of excitation conditions using a radiative trafer code RADEX. Thus, adopting a same beam size with cycle 0 data of VV114, our target sensitivity is 1.0 mJy/beam for 13CO(1-0). Assuming that VV114 is the representative object of our survey (size, luminosity, and distance), the CO observation of VV114 shows that the sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam for CO(1-0), which is for analysis of molecular gas conditions. Assuming CO(1-0)/CO(1-0) = 0.9 (VV114; Sliwa et al. 2013), our target sensitivity is 4.5 mJy/beam for CO(2-1) emission.
Binning up the velocity resolution to 10 and 30 km/s for CO lines and 13CO lines, respectively, we need 1.25, 2.08, 0.94, and 0.97 for 13CO(1-0), 13CO(2-1), CO(1-0), and CO(2-1).
We require CO(1-0) & 13CO(1-0) [Band 3], and CO(2-1) & 13CO(2-1) [Band 6] observations of 2 merging U/LIRGs. To resolve molecular gas clumps with similar resolution to Pa alpha observation of 1".0 (~ 400 pc), we need a spatial resolution of 1".0 and velocity resolution of 10 km/s for CO lines, and 30 km/s for 13CO lines to resolve complicated velocity structures of merging galaxies. In order to achieve required velocity resolution, we choose the 1875 MHz bandwidth and 488 kHz spectral resolution setting for all lines. In addition, these molelcular lines can help us detemine the driven chemistry of each merging galaxy (Saito et al. 2013; Martin et al. 2006), because this correlator setup covers strong CN(1-0), CS(2-1), and CH3OH(2-1) emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Elevated CO(1-0)/13CO(1-0) line ratio from 20 to 50 is often observed in the nucleus of infrared-bright merging galaxies. The mechanism is not fully understood yet although CO and 13CO emission are most useful extragalactic gas tracers. Our cycle 0 observations toward mid-stage merger VV114 demonstrated that high CO/13CO abundance ratio is more important to the elevated CO/13CO intensity ratio than low optical depth of the CO emission in the intense star-forming regions of the system. To develop the results for other galaxies, we propose 5.3 hours of ALMA cycle 2 time to obtain 1".0 resolution high-S/N CO(1-0), CO(2-1), 13CO(1-0), and 13CO(2-1) maps for 2 gas-rich merging galaxies, NGC 1614 and NGC 3110, enough to estimate gas conditions using an excitation analysis.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, The University of Tokyo

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
